Yes, Mercia was known for its thriving agricultural industry, particularly in the production of wool, which was one of its main exports. The kingdom had large flocks of sheep, and its skilled weavers produced high-quality woolen cloth and garments that were in high demand across Europe.

Mercia also had rich mineral resources such as iron and lead, which allowed the kingdom to develop a strong mining industry. The iron was particularly useful for crafting weapons and tools, contributing to the development of the kingdom's military power.

In addition, the location of the kingdom facilitated the development of other industries such as pottery and leatherwork. Mercian potters produced a distinctive style of pottery known as Staffordshire ware, which was popular in many parts of Britain. Leather tanning was also an important industry, with Mercian leather being particularly prized for its high quality.

Overall, Mercia's diverse economy, with its emphasis on agriculture, mining, and skilled crafts, helped the kingdom to thrive economically during its heyday in the 8th and 9th centuries.
